The film is a classic, and rediscovering it recently has been an awakening of sorts (Ive always been iffy on dark humor but now I fully embrace it). It has heart, and at times ridiculous, which makes it all the more enjoyable.

Only complaint was that the first disc I got was defective (it skipped the playback within certain scenes) and had to be replaced. Thankfully I got a full refund at the time (due to the holidays) and used it to buy a new one that played perfectly.

Great movie that still holds up 30 years later. I showed this to my 10 year old, who is starting to get into horror. It is such a clever movie, with a great balance of humor and horror. I was laughing, my 10 year old was fascinated, and my 9 year old couldn't watch because it was too scary for her. That's the kind of range it has. It's worth owning, and a must-have for any kid, especially ones who want to be thrilled.
Can't go wrong with the ultimate Christmas movie!  I introduced this movie to my daughter (as I saw the original run back in the 80's).  It was just as good today!

This witty, complex movie is filled with send ups from the classic stories of Christmas -- good and bad. As Roger Ebert wrote, " a meditation on the myths in our movies: Christmas, families, monsters, retail stores, movies, boogeymen. At the level of Pop Movie-going, it's a sophisticated, witty B movie, in which the monsters are devouring not only the defenseless town, but decades of defenseless clichés."

I enjoyed the first half more than the noisy, chaotic second half -- but the child in me loves it all.

Even the stereotypes -- Mother in Defense -- "Not in MY kitchen."

Not your typical Christmas movie, but every few years worth watching again to remember how it was.

Robert C. Ross
December 2017

There are already more than 3,800 reviews so this will be short.  I watched this with our 9 year old because she got something called a Feisty Pet for Christmas.  The toy reminded me of Gremlins and that she had not seen the movie.  She says the movie is really good and that the Feisty Pet designer(s) must have seen the movie.

One of the interesting things is that in addition to the actors playing the main characters, this movie features a number of faces recognizable as old time actors.  These include Kenneth Toby, Scott Brady and Harry Carey, Jr.  There were others whose names I could not recall.

We streamed the movie via Amazon rental with no problems.

Every time I watch this movie it just takes me back to my youth.  I can remember seeing this in theaters when I was younger and it stayed in my memories a good amount.  Several years later I bought it on VHS and everything that I loved about it as I kid plus the many things that I actually forgot about all got me to step back in time to the 80's.  Since then I watched it a bunch of times more and later on more times on DVD.

This movie is for all ages and for me it never gets old.  I find that every time I watch this movie I always catch something new going on in the movie that I never noticed before.  This movie packs quite a wallop whatwith this movie being a hilarious and sort of scary movie, the Gremlin monsters are  really menacing and awesome, the score/soundtrack is classic and just excellent, It's during Christmas time that all the horror, mayhem, and hilarity takes place, young actors and classic actors are both in the movie, finally it's from the 80's making it both nostalgic and showcasing the great awesomeness of the era.

Some Facts About the Film:  It was directed by Joe Dante and produced by by Michael Finnell.  It was written by Chris Columbus.  The musical score was by the late great Jerry Goldsmith. Among some of the notable stars are Zach Galligan(Hatchet III, Cyborg 3, Waxwork 1&2), Phoebe Cates(Fast Times at Rigdemont High, Princess Caraboo, Bright Lights Big City), Polly Holliday(Tv's Alice), Glynn Turman(TV's A Different World, The Inkwell) and Judge Reinhold(Fast Times At Ridgemont High, Head Office, Vice Versa)  The cinematography was by John Hora.  The Gremlins and Mogwais were created by Chris Walas.  The production company for the film was Amblin Entertainment.  It was distributed by Warner Bros.  The theatrical release date for the film was June 8, 1984.  The budget was $11 million dollars.  Finally the movie grossed $153.1 million dollars.

I just love the creature design for the Gremlins and the Mogwais by Chris Walas.  True the animatronics movements proved a bit stiff at times but at that time I had never seen such awesome and campy puppets before.  Not only was Gizmo cute and lovable but the other Mogwai were semi-cute and menacing to say nothing for the Gremlins especially Stripe which proved to be menacing and ruthless yet strangely cute themselves.  The movements for them were excellent for the most part.  What makes the Gremlins particularly evil and vicious and still hilarious and fun is how they emulate and poke fun at some many cliche' things that humans do.

About the humor, a couple of my favorite funny moments would definitely be for example:  All the hysterical things that they were doing in Dorry's Tavern including the one Gremlin wearing sweat clothes and legwarmers while break-dancing.  Another would be the scene where Stripe gets angry with the card dealer Gremlin and shoots him.  Or even the teasing Gremlin with the puppets on his hands annoying the Gremlin with the hat to the point of him hitting the Gremlin with the puppets in the head with a mallet.  As violent and rough as those couple of scenes might sound they were done in a bloodless and campy Looney Tunes and Three Stooges slapstick style.  That is just to name a few gutbuster hilarious moments.

Both the score by the late great Jerry Goldsmith and the songs on the soundtrack are excellent.  Jerry Goldsmith was always one of my top favorite film score composers and his work with this movie was among some of his greatest work ever.  His music here carries a lovely 80's vibe with it of course but also his melodies are very infectious and have an indelible earworm element to them as you are likely to be humming his tunes anywhere at any time plus they just plain stay in your head in general.  For the purpose of the movie Jerry comes up with not just the perfect moodset and emotion to go with the scenes but he goes from mellow, feelgood, and relaxing all the way to freaky and menacing without missing a beat.  As for the soundtrack well that included Michael Sembello(well-known for Maniac from the Flashdance soundtrack), Peter Gabriel, and Quaterflash.  While they were the only popular pop artists at the time doing only one song a piece on the soundtrack Their songs are still alot of awesome and fun classic 80's tunes.  Being a huge fan of all 3 artists their presence on this album proved completely welcome by me.

Joe Dante certainly has proven himself quite a great director when he did other great movies such as The Howling, Explorers(another of my  fond childhood memories), and The Burbs.  I have always enjoyed Dante's elements of humor, horror, weirdness, and at times sex appeal that his movies have often showcased.

I am highly impressed with John Hora's cinematography in this movie.  The interiors of the houses and public places are well shot and well edited both.  Just enough lighting, relatable looking house interiors, recognizable building interiors, and moody colors and shapes make for some excellent shots as well.  There's not alot to say about the exterior shots except that only as much as you need to see of the outside is shown.  Particularly when you get to see that the fictional town of Kingston Falls looks very much like a common Southern or Midwestern small town.

Most of the actors did a good at least decent job.  Corey Feldman was good as Pete.  Hoyt Axton was likable and believable as Rand Peltzer.  Phoebe Cates did an okay Job as Kate though it was a huge switch from her usually sexy roles to a squeaky clean small town girl.  Judge Reinhold was obnoxious yet quite funny as Jerold. Classic B-movie actor Dick Miller was tongue in cheek funny as Murray Futterman.  Polly Holliday was sensational as the vile and nasty b**** of a landlady Mrs. Ruby Deagle; she was also funny.  No complaints about anyone else with the exception of Zach Galligan.  His acting was horrendous then and to this day his acting is still ghastly.  He was a really poor choice as Billy and if he had been more focused on then the monsters he would have seriously ruined the whole movie.

Overall, if you love 80's horror, Christmas horror,  80's comedy, little monster movies involving the little monsters wreaking havoc such as Critters, Munchies, The Gate, or Ghoulies, love great 80's music, good camp, want something that even children can watch, good animatronics, and you enjoy references made to older actors and movies well then this movie is a must see.  After 33 years this movie still delivers on the horror and laughs!  10 stars out of 10!!

Purchased as a gift for my wife and it came fairly quickly considering that they used media mail option. Really glad I received considering media mail is for educational material only and had inspectors opened it would have been sent back. Not many ppl are aware of that I only know because My wife is a postal employee.

As for the packaging it was very very very will wrapped which I am extremely fearful for considering this is going to be a collector item.

It was received as pictured sealed in original packaging it was in very good new condition.

Thank you so much for the great car of the item.

Gremlins is a classic. You know what you're going to get before you see it (especially since its popularity placed a lot of the concepts into pop culture), but I will just say that on a technical level, the puppeteering and other special effects are truly amazing. Personally, I prefer practical effects to CG, especially for major effects, and Gremlins is a real tour de force in the regard. I saw this film a bunch when I was younger, but now I watch it with a pretty high respect for the technical work involved. It also has quite a few unforgettable scenes of mayhem and murder, so there's that too.

Do you want a good bout of nostalgia? Watch Gremlins! It isn't as scary as you remember, but it isn't really funny either. Ask the questions you should have asked when you were younger: why is a 23-year old man who works full-time living with his parents? Why is he best friends with a 10-year old boy? Why does that boy hang out in the man's bedroom and sit on his bed? Who taught the Gremlins to read? You'll have a fun evening.

Classic Christmas movie that teaches children responsibility and adults the value of cultural acceptance.  It also shows the value of having a job, and following your heart in your entrepreneurial endeavors.  With so many movies out there that are pure sleaze and violence, this movie shows that by working hard, and being true to yourself, you can achieve anything.  And...most notably, if something is hinky in your car, it's probably a gremlin.

The first time I saw this movie, back in 1984, I was too young and it scared the crap out of me, regardless of how cute Gizmo is or the humor injected into the film.  I was freakin four.  This only solidified my love for it, as stupid as some aspects are (ever read the original screenplay?  Nasty stuff!).  Never will the CG they use today look as real as the gremlins do in this film, even when you can see how fake they are.  If you've never seen this movie, watch it for the creature feature it is.  It's a good time, but really it's more PG-13 than PG...but that rating was very rarely used back then, like Ghostbusters or Poltergeist (the originals not the remake crap).

This movie came out when I was a teenager but I never felt a desire to watch it.  However, my husband painted it as a fun movie, so I decided to give it a try for nostalgia's sake, since so many of my teenage icons have been dying this year.  I could have died in peace without having watched it.  The pacing was agonizingly slow, even for a 1980's movie.  I joked with my kids that back when I was a kid, we had more patience, but this movie tested even my patience.  The lead actor seemed to be on Quaaludes most of the time, as well as Hoyt Axton and several others.  And the original gremlin, Mogwai, is rather creepy looking, even though they tried to make him cute.  And I suspect that he inspired Furby toy designs, which is another reason to dislike it.  There were a few funny parts, like the bar scene with the gremlins, but they were too infrequent and overwhelmed by gross scenes and the nasty scenes and the long,drawn out rising action, especially the fight scene in the hardware store.
Not only is this a classic but a required great for holiday for the family. Right before I scare my nerves and nephews into behaving!

Like all of us who originally saw the movie in the theaters when it was released, he fell in love with Gizmo, hated Striped and his ultimate large gang of buddies, and loved the bar and movie scenes. I had not watched the movie in years and while it seemed "tamer" than when I had first watched it, "Gremlins" is still a good time.

After he went to bed, I checked out the additional features in this Special Edition. There were stills with printed information, but I found the best parts are contained in the commentaries. I watched one with Director Joe Dante, cast members Zach Gilligan, Phoebe Cates, and Dick Miller, and Howie Mandel (voice of Gizmo). This was one of the most entertaining commentaries I had ever listened to. Many stories were recounted, and the five of them had a good time joking back and forth.

Definitely a lot of fun on one disc.

Great  movie.  I  think  though  there  is  one  thing  Steven Spielberg  hasn't  thought  of.  I  wonder  what  it  would  be  like  if  they  didn't  eat  after  midnight,  if  they  had  stayed  furry.  &  the  same  size  as  Gizmo.  I'd  love  to  see  them  wreak  havoc.  Or  get  into  mischief.  I  like  them  better  when  they're  like  Gizmo.  Its  Christmas  &  Mr  Peltzer  (Hoyt Axton)  is  out  Christmas  shopping  looking  for  a  present  for  his  son.  He's  an  inventor.  I  don't  think  he  was  trying  to  strike  up  a  deal  with  the  china  man  &  his  grandson  nor  trying  to  bribe  them.  He  didn't  seem  too  interested  in  his  inventions  anyhow.  Perhaps  there  was  a  time  when  the  Chinese  man  had  of  sold  the  Mogwai  Gizmo,  &  things  went  wrong,  now  he  won't  sell  it  to  anyone.  That's  probably  what  happened.  Peltzer  hears  humming.  &  goes  to  check  it  out.  The  Chinese  man  won't  sell  because  he  is  well  aware  that  folks  are  not  reliable  enough  for  the  results  if  they  do  not  follow  the  rules.  Little  green  men  can  multiply  from  getting  wet  &  start  going  crazy  terrifying  people  through  the  neighborhoods  or  wherever.
Now  the  grandson  watching  his  grandpa  walk  away  claims  he  is  stubborn  &  just  old.  So  he  waits  a  few  minutes  then  brings  out  the  little  box  with  Gizmo.
Because  Gizmo  needed  air  to  breath  He  insists  to  his  son  Billy  (Zach Galligan)  that  he  opens  it  up  now  &  not  wait  until  Christmas.  A  few  days  go  by,  all  seems  normal  as  Billy  enjoys  the  company  of  his  new  pet  aside  from  his  dog  Barney.  But  when  his  neighbor  Pete  (Cory Feldman)  comes  over  to  hang  out  he  asks  if  he  can  hold  Gizmo  &  accidentally  knocks  over  a  jar  of  water  Billy  had  used  to  rinse  his  paintbrushes  in.  Gizmo  is  screaming  as  he  wiggles  around  the  floor  acting  like  he's  in  real  pain.  Gizmo  I  suppose  is  actually  the  smartest  one  when  it  comes  to  an  understanding  about  gremlins  &  everything  that  goes  on  with  them.  He  knows  by  instinct.  &  yes  Mr  Peltzer  I'm  sure  every  kid  in  America  would  like  to  have  a  furry  little  creature  like  Gizmo.  By  the  way  would  you  still  call  that  a  gremlin  or  only  for  the  way  they  look  after  eating  after  midnight?  They'd  probably  make  a  mistake  somewhere  down  the  line  if  everyone  did  own  one  of  those  things.  1.  Keep  them  out  of  light  &  for  sure  sunlight.  2. No  water, baths,  or  none  to  drink.  3.  Don't  ever  feed  them  after  midnight.  &  after  the  first  half  hour  of  the  movie  that's  what  happens.  Billy's  clock  had  gotten  damaged.  It  was  plugged  in  by  the  wires  looked  they  had  been  chewed  on,  perhaps  by  Barney  or  the  gremlins.  He  looks  at  the  clock  &  then  goes  to  get  them  some  leftover  chicken.
Check  out  something  really  funny,  take  a  look  at  the  gremlins  when  they're  laughing,  like  they  were  when  they  drove  a  loader  through  Mr  Futterman's  home.  That  was  funny.  They  love  to  party  &  tare  up  the  town.  Probably  the  silliest  part  of  the  show  is  when  the  some  of  the  gremlins  visit  the  bar  where  Kate  works.
Some  of  the  gremlins  wearing  the  dark  sunglasses  looking  like  gangsters,  &  them  drinking  the  beer  didn't  seem  to  make  them  multiply  at  all.  What  I  laughed  at  was  when  Kate  took  a  picture  of  the  gremlins  with  her  camera  because  it  had  a  bright  flash  when  she  learned  they  were  afraid  of  bright  light.
They  finish  off  the  huge  crowd  with  a  gas  explosion  in  the  movie  theater,
&  chase  the  leader  with  the  white  stripe  to  a  sports  store,  &  it  is  Gizmo  who  saves  the  day  by  pulling  on  a  rope  &  exposing  the  bright  light.  Rand  Peltzer  (Hoyt Axton)  never  did  get  a  good  look  at  meaner  gremlins.  So  he  doesn't  take  part  in  too  much  of  the  action  throughout  the  movie.  Just  handles  his  fancy  looking  inventions,  meets  with  people  on  business  showing  them  his  inventions.  As  well  as  explaining  the  rules  to  Billy  after  bringing  Gizmo  home.
The  old  Chinese  man  appears  out  of  nowhere  being  disappointed  with  Billy's  father.  To  me  its  rude  to  enter  a  home  surprising  someone  without  knocking.
Perhaps  now  we  know  why  he  didn't  want  Rand  to  take  the  Mogwai  in  the  beginning.
The  ending  turned  out  fine.
Music  in  the  movie  is  fantastic.  I  recommend  this  movie  to  most  people,  not  everybody  because  some  people  just  can't  these  kind  of  movies.  But  please  compare  this  one  to  the  (Freddy Krueger  movies)?  This  one  here  is  what  I'd  call  a  decent  horror  movie.  Nothing  major  really.
For  the  record  the  gremlins  love  to  party  &  have  good  time.  They  don't  understand  that  somethings  should  be  kept  to  a  minimum.
They  try  to  have  a  blast  in  their  own  honor.
(Hoyt Axton)  did  a  good  job  narrating  the  beginning  &  ending  of  the  movie.

I told my daughters, 8 and 10, that this movie scared me so much as a kid I never watched it again. They thought it would be really cool to do a "face Mom's fears" night, and convinced me it probably wasn't *that* scary. Jokes on them, they were hiding their faces half way through the movie! I think my 8 year old is not going to let this go. As an adult, I tried to read between the lines. While my kids felt a little giddy reprieve during the bar scene, I saw a woman struggling to appease a horde of disgusting creatures blatantly acting out some of most despicable of human activities. Was that why these super intelligent creatures, who knew how to operate a stick shift moments after they were hatched, couldn't take down humanity? Because they were too enthralled by any impulse that compelled them to act like evil toddlers?  I feel like there is some big message about humanity here. And the mess, ugh. That's my new fear after watching this movie. A mess so big the best option is to simply condemn and evacuate the town. This was clearly not an enlightened time for society; those poor women were going to be sidelined into scrub duty while that big oaf of a father keeps making horrible machines that only make matters worse, not listening to warnings, and conveniently being out of town during the fallout.  If you want a peek into what second-wave feminism was so pissed off about, maybe you could include this movie in your research

I thought that this was going to be a funny Christmas movie with cute little furry creatures.

That is how it starts out.

But the cute little pet multiplies himself into evil little monsters called gremlins.

There really is no plot - - a 20-something year old guy named Billy who still lives with his parents gets an unusual pet from his father for Christmas.  The sweet pet multiplies himself into hundreds of creatures who - - for no reason - - want to cause damage to everything they see and kill everyone they see, until Billy manages to kill them all at the end.

There are ridiculous parts, like when Billy actually breaks a store window by banging it with a toddler's plastic toy.

There are disgusting parts, like when one of the gremlins is cooked to death in a microwave.

There are stupid parts, like where do these little creatures manage to get little outfits to wear - - one dresses up in a tiny trenchcoat and flashes people - - one dresses in a hat and sunglasses and smokes cigarettes and gets drunk - - they were just created and they already got wardrobes from nowhere.

There are weird parts, like when Billy hangs out in his bedroom with a ten year old boy (Corey Feldman).

This movie is very negative toward Christmas.  Phoebe Cates tells Billy a story about her father dressing up as Santa on Christmas Eve and dying horribly, which is how she realized that Santa is not real - - at the age of 9.  The only thing that made this a Christmas movie was that it takes place at Christmastime and there are Christmas decorations that get destroyed.

I watched this whole movie because I just had to see how it would end.

This movie was mostly disgusting, not at all scary, and too long.

This is a fun little horror movie that stood up pretty well to rewatching as an adult. I watched several times as a kid, but didn't remember a lot of what happened other than some of the more memorable action scenes (most notable the mom battling the gremlins in the kitchen). There is a lot going on in the movie, so much so that I missed out on some stuff due to not giving it 100% of my attention (like, what happened to the dog or that horrible greedy older lady). It's also amazingly gruesome and violent at times, something I think is missing from movies aimed at kids today. Or, perhaps my parents were crazy for letting me watch such "adult" stuff so young (I'm glad they did!).

Deducted a star for the flawed logic of the "rules", which kind of takes me out of the story as an adult (I remember it bothering me as a kid, too, wondering about stuff like time zones and atmospheric humidity). There's also the problematic racial issues, such as the use of the Magical Asian trope and the killing off of the only black guy in town- and that's without getting into discussion of the gremlins as the other invading white suburbia.

All in all, I'd recommend watching this movie if you want above-average 80s nostalgic fluff, great practical effects and puppetry, or if you are into analysing movies for social issues.

If you are wishing for 80's movie guilty pleasure or want to relive your youth, by all means order Gremlins.  However if you think this is a great movie for family movie night (for kids under 12 years old), think again!  For a PG movie, there is so much gratuitous maiming and killing it was shocking.  This would most definitely be listed as PG-13 if this movie was made today.  Another huge disappointment was the terrible and ridiculous story Phoebe Cate's character tells about how her father died several Christmas's ago.  For those children who still "believe", this movie is an absolute NO!

This movie is WONDERFUL!!! My mom bought this DVD a long time ago, and I grew up watching this. It could have used more bonus features, but I still adore it! This is, as the director put it, a "Gremlin and his boy" story about a young man named Billy Peltzer who's dad gives him a strange but cure little furry creature called a Mogwai that is given the name Gizmo. Mogwais have 3 special rules that you should never break: 1: Keep him out of the light. Especially Sunlight. Sunlight kills them. 2: Keep him out of the water. Don't get him wet. and the most important rule of all - 3: No matter how much he cries, no matter how much he begs - Never. EVER. Feed  him after midnight. But by accident and mischievious trickery, these rules do get broken, and results in spooky and hilarious fun for the whole family. The disc comes with 2 audio comentaries, one from the effects people and another from the director and actors Zack Gilligan (Billie Peltzer) Pheobe, the one who plays Kate, and Howie Mandel, who did the voice of Gizmo. Good for fans and people who are curious about this movie alike. Especially since there is talk of a Gremlins 3 that could be made in the near future.

Watched this with my son recently. Honestly, it is hard to believe that Spielberg produced this piece of dreck! The writing is uninspired and the characters are not only shallow but idiotic. Our "hero" manages to be shot in the arm by a cross-bow wielding gremlin in a sporting goods store and then is incapable of getting up off the floor? Really? And he drops his only weapon (a baseball bat) and suddenly is incapable of fighting back even as the gremlin threatens him with an electric chainsaw?
If this movie was supposed to be a combination of comedy and horror it fails badly on both accounts. The bar scene with gremlins everywhere is poorly executed, way too long, and features every stereotype possible (including a gremlin who flashes the female bartender).
If you want to save yourself and your family from the stench that is this movie, I highly recommend that you avoid this movie.

This is an offbeat black comedy about a horde of little monsters (Maguey) who invade the small town of Kingston Falls. Billy Peltzer, a young man (Zach Galligan)  is fooled into breaking 3 important rules concerning this new pet, Gizmo the maguey given to him by his eccentric inventor father, Randall Peltzer (Hoyt Axton).  What ensues is maniacal mayhem, a ton of funny gags, some good scares and non-stop thrills.  This horror/comedy hybrid is pure fun. It is nostalgic and a treat for movie fans There is a homage to the monster movies of the 1950s, 3D movies of the 1950s, invasion scares, small town America, Snow White, and It's A Wonderful Life. Populating the supporting cast of this film is a Who's Who of 1940s & 1950s and classic tv shows and movies: Keye Luke, Scott Brady, Harry Carey, Jr., Dick Miller, Polly Holiday, Edward Andrews, Glynn Turman, Jackie Joseph, William Schallert, Robbie the Robot,  and Kenneth Tobey. Also, look for early appearances by Phoebe Cates, Judge Reinhold, Corey Feldman, and Tom Bergeron. The movie is directed by Joe Dante, a master of horror, produced by the gifted Steven Spielberg, scored by Jerry Goldsmith. Michael Sembello's Gremlins Mega Madness theme is catchy and adds to the scenes of mayhem.

While the characters of Gizmo and the various Gremlins did become iconic characters in their own right (even inspiring the Furby toy craze of the late 90's), their movie just doesn't hold up as well any more.

This movie was somewhat marketed as a kids holiday film, when it was really a dark comedy.  There's a surprisingly high body count.  And the deaths, both human and gremlins related, are treated as punchlines.  But in regards to the comedy, a lot of the jokes sort of fall flat.  Which I feel like is a failing of the editing.

The only thing that really makes this feel like a kids movie is the Gizmo character itself.  Everything else just seems aimed towards teens to young adults.

There's good reasons to attempt to make a movie with broad appeal, but I feel like this movie lost its tonal consistency when it tried to be too many things.

The main thing that kept my interest in this movie was the puppetry.  The gremlins characters were well designed, and the way that the puppeteers performed them gave them a ton of character.  And for being practical effects from the 80's, the gremlins have an actual lifelike feel to them.  While Gizmo feels like a stationary anamorphic (because he is) the gremlins feel like actual living monstrosities capable of a full range of movement.  And they are some of the best realized puppets I've ever seen.

Special mention goes to the films score.  It's simple, and the Kremlin's theme repeats itself many times over the course of the film.  But its fun, and it does set a dark yet whimsical tone for the movie.  It's the one thing that keeps a consistent tone through the film.

Gremlins is a fine movie, though not one of Spielberg's best.  It's remembered for the characters, and for being one of the films that pushed the PG rating right up against an R with ratings creep.  This was one of the films that's credited for the creation of the PG-13 rating.  And it's best watched by going in expecting a popcorn movie with a dumb plot and some lame jokes.

GREMLINS works because it aims at, and hits several targets dead-center! It works as a comedy, utilizing both light and dark humor. It's a convincing horror movie, w/ the eeevil GREMLINS emerging, after the story starts out as a deceptively sweet, kid's story. It's also an effective morality tale, using the title creatures to illustrate the folly of human nature. As an homage film, GREMLINS is ingenious, somehow, simultaneously, paying tribute to divergent classics like IT'S A WONDERFUL LIFE, and monster movies such as INVASION OF THE BODY SNATCHERS! It also manages to retain an endearing charm, in spite of it's more sinister / horror elements. Director, Joe Dante pulled off quite a juggling act w/ this masterwork of macabre silliness! The human characters are memorable, the little creatures, whether good or wicked, are a wonder of practical sfx, and the re-watchable scenes are too many to list here! GREMLINS is certainly one of the best films of the 80's.

One of my childhood favorites right next to movies like "Back To The Future", "How The Grinch Stole Christmas", "Dumb & Dumberer: When Harry Met Lloyd" (Yes, the one that everyone hates!), "E.T.: The Extraterrestrial", "Firestarter", "Scary Movie 1-4", "Dude, Where's My Car?", "Drop Dead Fred", etc. I used to take a little "Gizmo" toy everywhere I went, I read all the books (I didn't read the novelization by George Gipe which I going to read soon), and I became a fan of Phoebe Cates, etc! This movie really means something to me! This is one of my top 20 favorite movie of all time right next to "Fast Times At Ridgemont High"! This is also one of my 8-year-old sister's favorite movies! I really wish I went and saw this in the theaters! I'll definitely see a remake of this in the theaters when ever they make one!

For those who've never seen or heard of it, it's about a guy named Randall Peltzer (Hoyt Axton, "Forest Gump", "Tropic Thunder") who's a very unsuccessful inventor who goes to Chinatown and finds a shop. He finds a mogwai and decides to get it. An old Chinese guy (Keye Luke, "Battle Of The Planets", "General Hospital") disagrees and tells Randall that he can't buy the mogwai. The grandson (John Louie, "Oh, God! Book 2", "Scout's Honor") ends up giving the mogwai to him and tells to never put him under the sunlight because it'll kill him, never give him a bath, and most importantly, never feed him after midnight! The next day, Randall's son, Billy (Zach Galligan, "Surviving", "Waxwork") and his dog Barney get threatened by Miss Deagle (Polly Holliday, "Mrs. Doughtfire", "Alice") which causes the dog to scare her. That night, Randall comes home and gives the mogwai to Billy as a Christmas present. The next night, Billy's neighbor, Pete (Corey Feldman, "Stand By Me", "The Goonies") accidentally spills water onto Gizmo. 5 other mogwais come out of Gizmo's back. Randall plans to sell the other mogwais, calling them "The Peltzer Pet". Billy accidentally feeds the other mogwais after midnight. The other mogwais turn into eggs. The eggs hatch. The other mogwais are now evil gremlins. They end up scaring Gizmo, Billy's dog, his mother (Frances Lee McCain, "Back To The Future", "Stand By Me"), his girlfriend, Kate (Phoebe Cates, "Fast Times At Ridgemont High", "Drop Dead Fred"), & the whole town!

This was a box-office smash hit! It got a sequel which is also really good! This is one of those movies that parents should be showing their kids! This is literally one of the best movies ever made!

This movie captured the hearts of countless when it was first made.  Over time it's become a Classic, each part of the movie is a work of art.

The story unfolds through:

Billy getting Gizmo.  The birth of the evil Mogwai.  The appearance of the pods, and the birth of the Gremlins.  Billy's mom destroying 3 Gremlins in her kitchen.  Billy saving her from a 4th, and Stripe's escape.

Stripe diving into a pool, creating an army of Gremlins - all his to command.  The chaos they unleash on the town is hilarious and brutal.  The horde of Gremlins traps Kate in the bar, and Billy saves her.  Then the horde's death by fire in the movie theater.  Stripe and Billy battling each other in the department store.  Finally Stripe's death at Gizmo's hands.

All so wonderful.

Like ET I could not escape this movie as a kid so it's become one of those movies that I've never given second thought to loving. Having just re watched it for the first time in 20 years I was shocked at how bad it is. It struck me that the central characters of Billy and Kate are written young but cast old. For example look at what falls out of Billy's stocking or what's in his room. There all toys. If this is meant to convey some sort of message about adulthood it doesn't play that way. Even Billy's friend Pete is a child and it's really weird. So if they remake it I really hope they make it a kids movie like the recent Earth to Echo which itself was a throwback to movies like The Goonies and The Monster
Squad. They most certainly will not go full on horror movie as it was originally intended so why not make a Pixar-esque family movie. I get that I'm pissing all over a classic here but I'm speaking objectively not blindly based on how I felt about it in the past. Trust me it's hard to let this go but there are plenty more classics from my childhood that still hold up so Gremlins is no love lost to me.

People who have not seen Gremlins or perhaps remember it as a funny little horror flick are surprised at the dark quality of the film.  The deaths and the gore and yuk shock them.  Gizmo is so cute, they made a fortune on all the toys.  It is an entertaining fun flick, but not for young children.  A inventive salesman, who can't invent anything that works, purchases a cute little creature in China Town for his son.  He is given a strict set of rules, which of course are not followed, and a group of evil mischievous Gremlins are released on their beautiful little town.  Murder and mayhem breaks out and the son and his girlfriend have to stop them before everyone is done in by the little monsters.  Well done and entertaining, but not for youngsters who may be mislead by the cute box cover.

This is NOT your typical feel good Christmas film. I advise this film only for cynically enamoured children or adults 13 and up. But if you like a tame horror movie experience straight from the 80's then this is for you. Merry Christmas?

I had forgotten there is a VERY DARK scene where the Phoebe Cates character talks about why she doesn't like Christmas. If you have youngish children who are into Santa Claus, this is probably not something you want to see.  It is pretty easy to skip through.  You'll see it coming when she starts monologuing with the male lead.  It has no other relation to plot.

SPOILER: Daddy went missing. They discovered him dead, dressed up as Santa, caught in the chimney.  I think it was Christmas Eve.

I have no idea why this scene was in the movie, as there isn't any happy redemption or way for her to get over it, nor does it add anything. It's kind of weird overall.  Guess it gives Phoebe a reason to mope around and some "depth". Once the Gremlin "fun" starts, she gets more animated.

Overall, just as entertaining as I remembered watching it when it came out. Especially good for tweener ages.

Junk Food! I can't help but like this movie. I just watched it again after almost 30 years (that's really hard to believe.) It's amazing to think this was all done before computer animation--the puppetry and animatronics are awesome. I will say that, as a film-maker myself, the writing and the cheese are rather ridiculous at times. 'have to remind myself that it's basically "a cartoon." The "My father died in our Chimney playing Santa Claus" monologue is totally absurd, out of place, and un-called-for. 'not sure what bitter memory Chris Columbus was stabbing in the heart of the holiday there--and maybe someone can explain why that's in the movie--a movie where Spielberg so carefully stopped Columbus and others from putting really "nasty" stuff in it (the mother was supposed to be decapitated, and Gizmo was originally to become Stripe, the evil leader.) Regardless, it is still fun. One other quick note: This movie instigated the PG-13 rating because it was too violent for PG and not bad enough for R. That's "of note" because my 7 year old was rather upset watching it. 'kinda forgot how violent it is--even though cartoonish. oops! 'had a 7-year old sleeping companion that night

Gremlins is one of my favorite 80's movies that I grew up as well as one of all time favorites.  I couldn't wait to own this new 30th anniversary edition, even though I pretty much own this movie on virtually every format (even laserdisc).

The only thing I'll discuss in my review is the new stuff offered in this "Diamond Luxe Edition" of this movie.  I'm pretty sure that disc #1, is exactly the same as the previous bluray release that includes the movie and a bunch of special features.  If you own the previous release and all you care about is the movie itself, then I'd recommend just holding onto that movie and saving your money. Also please note, that these new Diamond Luxe releases have some great packaging that makes me look forward to upcoming WB releases in this format.  Perhaps a 30th anniversary Goonies next year...

Disc #2 is for the Gremlin fan and completist.  It contains all new material that all versions before it did not include, primarily because the 2 featurettes were filmed this year to coincide with its 30th anniversary.  There is also an on-set feature with Hoyt Axton who played dad Rand Peltzer that was filmed in either 1983 or 1984 as he takes the viewer around the WB lot while he was filming Gremlins.  The last bonus feature are 2 digital motion comics that were taken from these storybooks that also came out in 1984 called "The Gift of the Mogwai" and "The Last Gremlin".  These were little storybooks offered at Hardee's restaurants when the movie came out that included a record that you could read along as you listened to it.  Unfortunately, this feature only features the first and last book in that series.  It would have been nice that all 5 of those books had been given the motion comic treatment but it was still nice and nostalgic to see those once again.  I'll have to get mine out of storage one of these days.

Now my big gripe about this is not towards the product itself but how Warner Bros. handled it a couple of weeks ago by announcing that this new edition of Gremlins (along with 4 more titles) will solely be a Best Buy exclusive only a mere week and a half before the September 30th street date.  Had I not been such a big fan of this movie I would wait until mid-December when all retailers get it.  I had it on preorder here on Amazon only to cancel my order so I can get it right away from Best Buy.  I won't go into much detail but when looking in my area when this came out last week it was next to impossible finding one.  Either Best Buy only ordered 2 for the rack or didn't order it at all when it was advertised in their weekly sales ad.

Overall, if you are a diehard Gremlins fan, then I recommend grabbing this one.  The new special features contain some great stuff including a scene described by Zach Galligan with an Easter Egg that in my dozens of times seeing this and knowing it word for word contains something that I completely missed.  Check it out!

GREMLINS, A classic 80's film
Gets a new blu-ray re-issue from Warner bros to mark it's 30th Anniversary
this new re-issue on 2 Discs has new packaging and new special features plus the old special features from the 2009 blu-ray release
the packaging is not a standard case,
it's a fold out Digi-pak with very hard case covers like Hard plastic which is called Diamond Luke packaging
i prefer the standard blu-ray case not a fold out Digi-pak
Disc 1 has the feature film in the exact same blu-ray transfer & exact same widescreen ratio as the 2009 release
WB did not give the film a new transfer and just left it as it is.
the special features on Disc 1 are exactly the same as the single Disc 2009 release
all the old Audio commentary tracks, Additional scenes, Deleted scenes, outtakes
Behind the scenes footage, everything from the 2009 release is on this Disc no Difference at all

Disc 2 has the new special features released for this 30th Anniversary
a  new 30mins retrospective featurette
new interviews with writer Chris columbus, executive producers Steven spielberg, Frank marshall, Michael Finnell
and Director Joe Dante
the only Actor interviewed is Zach Galligan actually
Phoebe Cates left the Acting business over 10 years ago so of course she's not interviewed
she Did the Audio commentary for the DVD release years ago which is on Disc 1 of this blu-ray anyway
Judge reinhold & Corey Feldman are also not interviewed for some reason
but Judge reinhold did the Audio commentary for the dvd release anyway
Actor Hoyt Axton passed away years ago anyway
still a very interesting 30 min's that's for sure

the 2nd featurette goes for about 20mins is a new interview with creature effects artist Chris walas
who gives his recollections on making the Gremlins creatures
the producers and Joe Dante from the first featurette are also interviewed
there is also On set footage with Actor Hoyt Axton goes for 5mins
plus 2 motion comics from the 1984 Gremlins book

altogether both new featurettes go for 50mins in total
and WB could've easily put it on the 1 blu-ray Disc with the film for sure
blu-ray has more Data space than dvd
but obviously WB chose to stretch the content out on 2 Discs

the U.K. blu-ray release of this new 30th Anniversary
which is ALL REGIONS is standard blu-ray case packaging with 2 Discs inside
which is shown on amazon uk website
both the U.S. and U.K. 30th Anniversaries of Gremlins have exact same content, have exact same blu-ray transfer
i prefer the standard blu-ray case i bought my copy from amazon uk
but up to you which version you want

Definitely time to upgrade and get this new 30th Anniversary edition which has old and new special features
5 stars for sure for this new blu-ray re-issue.

Since almost everybody has seen Gremlins by now, I won't waste any time explaining how great this classic film is, but rather inform readers that the new bonus features of the 30th anniversary edition distinguishes itself from the previous 25th anniversary edition.  Warner Brothers has not officially announced that the special features from the 25th edition will make its way to the 30th anniversary edition, but it is assumed they will.  For now, I have listed the new special features of the 30th edition.

Bonus Special Feature:
From Gizmo to Gremlins: Creating the Creatures (New) - Special effects wizard Chris Walas plus the filmmakers and cast guide us through the art of creating Gremlins, Gizmo and Stripe, how the puppets worked (or didn't!) and how their voices came to be.
Cute. Clever. Mischievous. Intelligent. Dangerous: Making Gremlins (New) - Steven Spielberg tells how he found the screenplay for Gremlins and why it was perfect for his then-new company Amblin Entertainment. Dante, Marshall and Finnell also participate.
Motion Comic of the 1984 Book "Gremlins: The Gift of the Mogwai" (New)
Motion Comic of the 1984 Book "The Last Gremlin" (New)
Hangin' With Hoyt on the Set of Gremlins (New)
Greater.

TO BE UPDATED ONCE THE BLU-RAY IS RELEASED.  FOR NOW, MY VIEWS ON THE FILM ITSELF.

Back in the day, when this movie was released in theaters, I was merely a child, too young to even be able to read.  A couple of years later, though, I got to see this movie on TV.  And it made such an impression on me I feared the dark for years after watching it.

Gremlins tells the story of a young boy who's given a unique Christmas gift by his father.  An inventor of crazy contraptions, the father enters a weird store ran by an old asian wise man while looking for a gift.  There, he meets Gizmo, an impossibly cute strange little furry creature called a "Mogwai" and instantly wants it.  After being denied the purchase by the owner, he makes a deal with an employee and gets to bring the creature home, with a list of strange rules for its care: Never let Gizmo be exposed to bright light, never get him wet and never feed him after midnight.

Bright light, as it turns out, harms Gizmo, so they avoid it.  But the other rules have no explanation, so they leave the family curious.  Unfortunately, soon enough those rules are accidentally broken.  Getting Gizmo wet makes him reproduce, creating a bunch of other little creatures, as cute as him but clearly far less nice.  The real bad part comes when they're accidentally fed after midnight.  It so happens that this makes the Mogwais transform into the eponymous Gremlins, wicked, mischievous and (in the case of punk-haired Spike) even plainly evil reptilian small monsters, which then proceed to wreak havoc in the small town, and it's up to the boy, his girlfriend and Gizmo to stop them.

Now, this film is one of cinema's most beloved classics.  The story is a strange tale of fantasy and terror, with dark humor and tons of ingenious references (for instance, at some point, the father is demonstrating an invention while on the background we can see a guy sitting on the Time Machine from H. G. Wells story, pressing a lever, then there's a cut and when we see the background again the machine is gone, leaving just a puff of smoke).  While the sequel would go on to be full humor, this film had some truly terrifying bits.  This comes specially at the end, when there's a warning that implies the creatures could be real, and you should always check on dark places.  To a small child, this can be very shocking, and I assure you, I checked under my bed before going to sleep for a long time before I realized Gremlins wouldn't be real.

One of the best parts of the film are, of course, the special effects.  Being released when it was, the film had no CGI, it was all made with practical effects, and they were glorious.  They still hold up to this day, and they're always a joy to watch.  You will believe Gizmo has a soul, and you will be terrified to see Spike's grimace.

The previous Blu Ray release of this film was very lackluster in quality and features.  Let's hope this one changes things for the best.  I will update the review as soon as I get hold of this release, in order to speak of the Blu Ray itself.

I love nontraditional Christmas movies.  If they have a little bite and backbone to them so much the better.  This one involves a desperate father (Hoyt Axton) trying to find a Christmas gift for his son (Zach Galligan).  In an antique store in Chinatown, he finds a gift in the form of a cuddly creature called a Mogwai.  The critter comes with a set rules that are immediately broken so that the worst case scenario can take place.  Several generations later, vicious gremlins emerge and wreck havoc in the small town of Kingston Falls.  Death, destruction, and ruin follow suit (plus a great deal of skewed humor).  Polly Holliday channels Margaret Hamilton as the town witch (Mrs. Ruby Deagle) with a vendetta against Billy's (Galligan) dog.  Most of the cast do a splendid job with the roles they were given, especially Dick Miller as Murray Futterman.  If you get sick of all the treacle served up by most Christmas movies, watch this one for a change of pace.  It's nothing less than fun.

Made in 1984, I can't ever remember a time that Gremlins wasn't part of my December.  Steven Spielberg gives us this borderline terrifying movie coupled with hilarity, jokes, and slapstick to get us through what could have been a potential horror flick.  A father buys his son a gift in the form of a Mogwai, a cute little ball of fur with big bat ears, for Christmas.  This cute, adorable, little pet has only three rules.  1) They hate bright lights and sunlight can kill them, 2) They should never be gotten wet, and 3) They should never be fed after midnight.  Gizmo, the name of the Mogwai, becomes fast friends with Billy, the son, but when an accident happens getting Gizmo wet, a whole world of trouble is brought to their sleepy, snow-ridden town during that particular Christmas.

Gremlins is a fun, fast movie, for people of all ages, and has been a name stay during the holidays since it came out nearly three decades ago.  This particular DVD has a few special features, like 10 minutes of extra footage, commentaries, behind-the-scenes documentaries, and the trailer.  It's definitely worth the few bucks you would spend on it and is sure to provide your family and yourself with much entertainment over the years.

This happened to be on "free" TV today, and I was too lazy to change the channel.  And so while working on a computer, doing something almost as scary as this film -- installing Windows 8 on a Samsung Tablet -- I watched and listened to this epic disaster.

I clicked the "Info" button on my favorite television provider, and I was shocked to see that 80 percent or more of critics liked this thing!  How is that even possible?  Perhaps they were taken hostage by the scary little Gremlins in the film, and told that, if those critics gave a bad review, that they would be tied up and forced to watch the film over and over, until their eyes and their ears bled out?

Well, on the bright side, their is Phoebe Cates.  She's certainly not scary, at least to look at.  But if you're over five years old, how can you appreciate a film with fake little puppets, bad acting, and no real adult humor?  This would be a big pass by me.

I watch this movie today and see that its not as great as I thought it was.. even though its very funny and fun.
but from my POV I see a treatise on the socio-economic situation of that particular time that is relevant today.  the protagonists household is a warm and loving one, even though everything is falling apart and nothing seems to work.  they rely on this stuff(material gain) and of cousrse it all seems to bite them in the butt everytime they slam the front door..which is portrayed as the real dysfunctionality of the family unit.  it seems to be saying that we have too much stuff, and too much stuff is what doesnt work.  also, this movie seems to profile certain ethnic persons as being a problem too.  If you notice amongst the ner do well types represented by the gremlins you will find ghetto-blaster totting, break danceing, gremlins mixed right in with the junky gremlins, drunk gremlins, ski masked criminal gremlins, hipster/beat gremlins, and gangster strong-arm gremlins(gremlin, ie Stripe).  Yes folks, these types are portrayed as the gremlins in the social mechanism that makes life a living hell for all us lace curtain mo-foes out there trying to live our lives in peace.  I also have to add this little one in there:  they introduce the break dancing gremlin in a rather homosexual light with the stereotypical PINK leg warmers and all.. and if you notice there is some cross-dressing going on amongst the gremlins as well.  yeah, these are the types that are the monkey-wrenches in the societal machinery.  I don't believe in accidents in films because there is soooo much incredible thought put into every last detail of every scene made in a film(it comes down to financial planning).  Theres also the treatment of the evil heartless bankers and landlords thrown in there for good measure;  "mommy im hungry.. yes honey, im hungry too..".  Its a veritable smorgasbord of elitist commentary on what they think is wrong with all us little folk.  but wait!  who's going to save us?!..well The college kids of course! The new reich! the new useful idiots(as lenin liked to call them)!  Oh yeah! but also, what kills these horrid wretched gremlins in the system?  light! illumination!  these freeeeks hate the light and illumination of politically correct and double checked mainstream knowledge, because they're so effed-up and ignorant.  No doubt about it, the illuminated youth movement is our only hope.  HAIL!
 so let us not water-down the real problems in our society lest they go unchecked and multiply! Lets not feed our social/mental/spiritual midnight, because thats when all the freaks come out.  Rather, let us combat them with truly ILLUMINATED minds..and kill em all.
Its either that or its just a mediocre comedy/monster movie.
Dont go taking it too seriously. ;)

With its inane mix of genres, attitudes and inspirations, there's really no good reason for this movie to work as well as it does. Like the ubiquitous creatures at the heart of the plot, Gremlins delights in mayhem. The proud owner of a restless spirit and a tendency to rattle the gearbox at the slightest hint of a lull, the film can be splendidly unpredictable, charmingly sweet and morbidly profane, sometimes all within the same scene. It's vividly violent, often shockingly so, but still touts a wild sense of humor and an unexpected knack for sentimentality. I was pleasantly surprised at the lengths it was willing to go to, considering no member of the cast indispensable, and that left me hooked right up until the closing showdown. It's not the perfect picture - there are holes in the plot large enough to roll a bulldozer through - but as a sharp, silly change of pace in the holiday season, one could do far worse.

This is a nicely done tale. It has warmth, feeling, and shock value in a cute & entertaining way. Could have done without the racist remark at the end of the movie, but unfortunately; when people in the entertainment field get a little too much Fame and or Money; they get the grandiose idea that their political feelings should of course be everyone's viewpoint. Steven Spielberg, for as formulamatic as his films are, has found his niche in life; even if it is mostly in his own mind. I don't know how many times I have said it or heard someone else exclaim it after being ambushed with a racial or political aside in what is supposed to be a mere entertainment diversion- Keep your Politics to yourself! If the film were about Aliens then his comment could have been taken as a blanket statement about the human condition. Since the IDMB website lists these (imaginary) creatures as an animal indigenous to China that somehow turn into Demons when not cared for properly; we cannot assume the aforementioned. I watch movies for they're entertainment value, not what the Producer or Director flavor of the week thinks about other Races or Political issues. It's 1 of the main reasons Fun With Dick And Jane with Jim Carrey was a forgettable movie along with many others. Hey! We don't want to hear it! As mid October rolls around, brisk winds sweep through the crisp autumn air, jack o'lanterns decorate steps and porches, the scent of wood smoke radiates from wood stoves, and the leaves are in their peak season of color. October is a magnificent month, and in celebration of its annual visit, I've decided to review a few great flicks for the Halloween season. The titles that I've chosen to review are "alternative" Halloween movies... not the classics that generally spring to mind, but fun movies with elements of the supernatural. Just good, lighthearted stuff here... nothing gory or scary (at least not too much)!

"Gremlins" is both hilarious and entertaining. The little critters are truly charismatic and mesmerizing (at least until they undergo their rather disturbing transformation, when fed past midnight or exposed to water!). Obviously, the special effects for this movie are quite dated (it's almost thirty years old now), but "Gremlins" was a staple of cinema for any child of the 80s. It's still quite entertaining (and comforting, in a strange way), though I suspect it may not be as well received by younger audiences who are used to modern productions. For those of us who grew up in the  80s, however, "Gremlins" is still gold, and a great "alternative" Halloween movie for the season of spookiness.

First off let me say the first time I saw this movie I was around 5 or 6 & it scared the living daylights out of me. I am now a 22 year old woman & the gremlins series are two of my favorite "scary movies" I watch them every time I see they are on, laugh the entire time I watch them, & will be buying this movie. For all the people complaining about how bad the acting is & blah blah blah guys this movie was made in 1984 not 2004 & is supposed to be a raunchy,comedic, semi-horror movie. Is it scary? Heck yes it's scary, the first time you watch it. If you show it to your kids they're probably gonna have some problems sleeping for a few nights, but guess what my parents told me when I got like that when I was younger? "It's just a movie, go to sleep. *turns lights out*" Guess what? I learned to tell myself it's just a movie (even if I had to say it to myself 2000 times til I passed out)& go to sleep, the next morning I would wake up smiling because nothing happened to me & realized that scary movies are just that, movies. They're not real. & I'm fine now, no therapy, no irrational fears of the dark, no dreaming about Gremlins coming to get me. If anything this movie's a lesson in following instructions, Peter was clearly told not to get it wet or feed it after midnight & he did anyways soooo it's kinda his fault things went sour. The 80s and 90s were full of movies & shows that didn't have cheery songs & happy go lucky characters in them that although frightening we still appreciate now. I watched Nightmare on Elm Street, Halloween, Child's Play, Are You Afraid of the Dark, Candyman and Pumpkinhead & I screamed  and hid under the covers every time but I loved every second of it just as much as I loved Disney movies. Stop babying your kids, being afraid isn't going to kill them.

A rather incompetent inventor goes into a curiosity shop in Chinatown looking for a Christmas gift for his teenage son. He comes across an odd little creature, as adorable as a teddy bear, called a Mogwai. He wants to buy it, but the old man who runs the shop says it's not for sale. The old man's grandson, however, says they need the money, and he brings it out to sell in the alley. Along with the Mogwai comes three rules for taking care of him: (1) he does not like bright lights; (2) don't get him wet, and (3) most important, never, ever feed him after midnight.

Of course, all three rules are eventually broken, and the results are scaly green gremlins that run riot all over town. As I say, the bar-room scene is quite hilarious. A large group of them are cornered in the movie theater (where some more great visual jokes are done), but Stripe, the leader of the gang, gets into the department store across the street.

The cute little Mogwai, named Gizmo, eventually triumphs, but how he does is the funniest movie you'll see in many a year.

Casual fans of the film probably won't rush out to pick up the "Gremlins: 25th Anniversary Edition" Blu-ray. The film wasn't remastered or restored for this release. The special features and improved audio will convince dedicated consumers to pick this up no doubt.

I'm not ashamed to admit - I had a stuffed Gizmo when the film came out. This is one of three or four movies that I watched incessantly when it was first released. I finally decided to reach back into my childhood and see if the BD was worth the effort. And my answer - a resounding yes!

Some BDs of 70's and 80's films don't come with a very pretty restored picture. Not so here. Since there are more puppets than not, the special effects are outstanding. The special features are on the light side, but you don't grab BDs for those, unless you're me. The commentaries are fun, especially the director and lead actors Zach Galligan and Phoebe Cates. There are some new/exteded scenes, and a dated making-of featurette (which is not to say it's worthless, it's just dated). The audio channels are actually beterr than anticipated, with a heavy TrueHD 5.1 right on the top (I still miss 7.1 though). There's a ton of subtitle tracks as well, which as I always say, is greatly appreciated.

An evil gremlin wanders onto the Deagle estate and reads the sign in front of the house saying, "Deeeaggle, Deagle, Deagle, Deagle".  The gremlin enters the house and spots a Pepsi can on the kitchen table saying, "Pepsi, Pepsi, Pepsi".  The gremlin then makes a move to grab the beverage.  All of a sudden, Mrs. Deagle comes haphazardly into the kitchen and grabs the can without noticing the gremlins presence.  As Mrs. Deagle pops the can open and drinks she heads back to her electric chairlift to elevate to the top floor the Gremlin looks at her with a vengeful scowl on the face thinking, 'it's payback time old hag'.  The gremlin dashes to fuss with the chairlifts wiring system.  As Mrs. Deagle sits on the chair she pushes the button and the circuitry goes haywire launching her at top speed through the window and she hits the ground with both feet in the air.  The camera then shows a pack of gremlins with Pepsi cans in their hands singing fa cha cha cha cha cha with big smiles on their faces.  Pepsi...let's talk about this.

The 1984 movie "Gremlins" boasts a spectacular blend of comedic and horror elements, and is a uniquely crafted popular classic.  The diverse cast includes Hoyt Axton, Zach Galligan, Phoebe Cates, Polly Holliday and Keye Luke.

The story, by noted director Chris Columbus, is by now familiar to many people.  A loving but stubborn father makes a detour into an eccentric shop which is overseen by a wise proprietor.  Upon seeing the exotic creature called a Mogwai, the father eventually cuts an illicit deal for the Mogwai with the shop owner's well-meaning but short-sighted grandson.  There is a little matter of three famous rules for Mogwai care which inevitably get broken and lead to horrific results.

The Gremlin creatures are genuinely gross, malevolent little beasts, and as their numbers multiply it is very believable that they can terrorize a town, making creative allowances for fiction.  Impressively, even today, they are not a dated special effect or puppet but credible characters in the film who ooze danger and menace.

I mentioned this film was a comedy and it is, but most of the humor is of a muted, vaguely dark variety.  A good example is when a Gremlin in a mailbox throws letters back out at a man who put some into the box.  There is also an oddly comedic scene in a movie theater, with many Gremlins happily watching Walt Disney's "Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs."

Polly Holliday is suitably nasty as Mrs. Deagle, the mean-spirited old lady who has a grudge against Billy Peltzer, the movie's main protagonist.  Zach Galligan is credible and sympathetic in that role, and Phoebe Cates is perfect as Kate, Billy's sweet co-worker and girlfriend.

Also featuring Corey Feldman, Judge Reinhold, and solid direction by Joe Dante, "Gremlins" is very, very good.

P.S. Howie Mandel voices the sweet Mogwai, dubbed 'Gizmo' by Billy Peltzer's father.

An unexpected choice, but a classic scary Christmas movie nonetheless, Gremlins has held up surprisingly well. The actual Gremlins are too frightening for the youngest children, but it's a great film for families with older kids or adults who enjoy pratfalls and special effects.

The movie -- I first saw Gremlins when I was a teenager, and I was drawn to the anarchic, irreverent, dark humor of the film. Seeing it decades later as an adult has rubbed off some of its luster -- the pacing is odd at times, and the synthesizer soundtrack is dated. Some of the special effects look clunky, such as the puppets used in some of the long shots. (But I prefer them to today's CGI effects, which look cold and sterile.) I still think it's an entertaining movie, though.

Image Quality of the Blu-ray -- This Blu-ray disc is the best I've seen this film look on home video. However, don't get your hopes up. This movie was a low budget affair shot on film stock with grain the size of golf balls. It's never going to look as clean as today's slick, plastic movies, even remastered in High Definition.

The Extras -- Extras are plentiful. There's two commentaries by the director Joe Dante and crew, outtakes and deleted scenes, and a TV special that aired back in the 80's to promote the feature.

Gremlins has a reputation as a film for children, probably because of Speilberg's involvement, and the cute Gizmo character. However, this movie, along with Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom, was controversial because its use of violence was too intense for a PG rated film. The PG-13 rating was created because of this. It would benefit parents to consider that if they're thinking of buying this video for their kids.

The sleepy town of Kingston Falls is in for a world of trouble when Billy receives a cute little pet Mogwai for Christmas. Billy is given three easy rules to follow to keep his pet safe, but when he breaks two of them by mistake, the creature spawns a horde of mischievous little monsters that are bent on murder and mayhem! It is a Christmas we will never forget in GREMLINS, the classic creature-feature from 1984 that has left a permanent impression on pop-culture. Joe Dante works from various childhood influences like Looney Tunes and Merry Meoldies to create a wacky world of cartoon chaos, using the incredibly artistry and animatronics of Chris Walas to bring these tiny terrors to life. The creature designs are so nasty and finely articulated that they become indistinguishable from real life. Steven Spielberg's influence is always apparent in the picturesque setting of Kingston Falls. That is, until the Gremlins take over! What starts with cruel jokes and minor tampering turns into full blown madness as the monsters tear up the town and terrorize the neighbors. Dante always keeps the mood lighthearted and fun for all ages despite some of the darker tones and frightening monsters. Add to that the unforgettable characters created by Zach Galligan, Phoebe Cates, Hoyt Axton, and the legendary Dick Miller, and you have a timeless classic to carry on the holiday horror tradition for years to come.

-Carl Manes

"Gremlins" is one of the great guilty pleasures of motion pictures. It's an absolute classic, tremendous fun every time you watch it. As one reviewer said, it's "a hoot".

Though "Gremlins" comes across as a perverse take on the holiday cheer of "It's a Wonderful Life" (the dis-connection is explicitly made within the film), one cannot overlook "Forbidden Planet". Just as the "Great Machine" allowed the Krells' inner demons to take physical form, so are the gremlins a representation of our normally suppressed murderous impulses. Otherwise, why would Billy Peltzer * be so careless about the rules?

This is not as much of an interpretive stretch as it seems. Most of the scenes in which the "bad" or unlikeable characters are punished or killed were removed from the final cut. Mrs. Deagle (the film's equivalent of Old Man Potter) is murdered in a grotesquely comic manner, but the scene which "justifies" her offing (she's forcing the bank to foreclose properties on which a chemical plant will be built) was deleted. (Though the director's desire to keep the film moving along is justifiable, most of these scenes should have been restored for home video.)

In Renoir's "Boudu Saved from Drowning", the title character is another "id monster" whose animal presence utterly disrupts a middle-class family. There's little doubt that Stripe blowing his nose on the curtains is an homage to Boudu wiping his shoes with a satin bedsheet.

"Gremlins" also has an element of Hitchcockian voyeurism. One of the film's "pleasures" is watching punishment meted out to those deserving it, through an agency (the gremlins) whose behavior we are not responsible for. Our "murdering id" can be vicariously gratified without legal or moral consequences.

"Gremlins" anticipates films like "Puppet Master", "Hostel", and "Saw", which tittillate the audience with scenes of people being murdered or mutilated in a graphic, detailed fashion. **

"Gremlins"' iconic scene, in which Billy's mother kills three of the gremlins -- by grinding up one in a mixer, stabbing another repeatedly, and (classically) blowing up one in a microwave oven -- was the one that most aroused audiences (both pro and con), as it cuts close to the bone of how we would /sometimes/ like to handle our personal problems. Mrs. Peltzer isn't killing rats -- the gremlins are sentient, consciously malicious beings. Like, your boss, maybe?

In the running commentary, Joe Dante remarks several times that, had CGI been available, "Gremlins" would have been an altogether different film. Indeed. One of the film's charms is the audience's awareness that it is watching fur-and-rubber puppets "live" on the soundstage, performing an especially nasty "Punch & Judy" show. CGI just wouldn't be as much fun.

The Blu-ray transfer ranks a B -- "Gremlins" was not a sharply detailed film in the first place. (The image quality suggests an excellent projection print, rather than the camera negative.) On the other hand, one can better appreciate the beautifully complex lighting. And let's not forget Jerry Goldsmith's terrific score, one of his best. It's a pleasure to hear a score in which instruments are selected for their particular effect (a la Herrmann), and which doesn't continually drone on.

Unhesitatingly recommended.

* The name suggests the verb "pelts". The gremlins are very good at throwing things.

** It wasn't the first. "The Abominable Dr. Phibes" (and its sequel) were quite gruesome, but nothing much was said about the violence.

When Billy Peltzer is given a small creature called a Mogwai by his father, he is unaware of the carnage he is about to encounter. There is a huge responsibility in looking after Gizmo as there are certain rules which must be followed. The Mogwai must be kept away from bright light, never made wet and never, ever be fed after midnight. When an accident occurs involving Gizmo and water, the next evolution stage of the Mogwai appears, and it isn't nice at all. Gremlins is a fantastic comedy movir from 1984. It's funny seeing the Gremlins cause mischief but it's also scary throughout-they're not exactly pretty creatures and are quite scary as well. This was one of Joe Dante's first movies and you can tell that everything he grew up with and movies he studied as a child are on-screen in Gremlins. A perfect movie made by the right director.

Ok, so it IS an entertaining film and has lots of laughs despite how corny it is at times. What I can't figure out, though, is who this movie is supposed to be for. It's definitely not for little kids - there is far too much violence and blood (even though the blood is green). Bad Gremlins doing adult things and exploding in microwaves mean this is not a 90 minute babysitter for the little ones. Gremlins was one of the films that pushed the ratings board to create the PG-13 rating. On the other hand, teenagers & above will probably find it a bit too cutesy and childish to appeal to them. Whatever - at eight dollars, you're sure to find some use for it!

This is not worth the upgrade for the cost it is going at right now. WB did not remaster Gremlins for Blu-Ray. In my opinion (and many others) the BD is only a small improvement over the DVD. I'd say the improvement in clarity and detail varies between 5%-30% better throughout the film. The audio is much better though, really fun to hear the score in HD audio. Wait till the price drops, then pick it up.

...You watch it and find yourself sucked into an otherwise story by numbers movie (hey, the old guy says "no sunlight, water or food after midnight" so you're warned what to expect already). Main criticism of course is its lack of focus on the hilarious antics of the evil Gremlins (something the sequel did a little better) who destroy a good portion of a town, but aren't seen nearly enough to make you detest them - instead they're little more than pests.  The level of gore is surprising, which is how you can tell that this isn't technically a "kids" movie, so care should be taken with young children (but saying that I'd have been 7 when I saw this and had no problem....but then Nightmare on Elm Street might have desensitised me a bit by that time) but it's essential viewing if only so that you can watch the sequel too.
One of my Favorite 80s movies. I love it. My kids love it. A classic.

thanks had been a long time since I had seen the movie. Brought back happy memories.

Don't expose them to sunlight. Don't let them get wet. And under no circumstances feed them after midnight.

Those are the rules for the now-legendary mogwai, adorable little fuzzballs who transform if you break the last rule. And "Gremlins" is a gloriously unconventional Christmas movie -- a postcard-pretty view of suburban middle-America, splattered with gore, nasty little gremlins and a truly wicked sense of humour (expressed often in movie send-ups).

Randall (Hoyt Axton) spots a tiny adorable creature -- a mogwai -- in a small Chinatown shop, and wants to buy it as a Christmas present for his son. The owner refuses, but his grandson secretly sells it to Randall.

Randall's son Billy (Zach Galligan) is delighted by the fuzzy lightphobic mogwai, whom he names Gizmo. But it soon becomes clear that Gizmo is full of surprises: when water is accidentally splashed on him, he spontaneously generates a litter of NEW mogwai. The ringleader "Stripe" tricks Billy into feeding them after midnight, transforming them into scaly, dangerous "gremlins.

And after a gremlin tumbles into a pool, Billy realizes that the town is about to be swarmed with them -- attacking vicious old Mrs. Deagle, ramming snowplows, murdering kindly teachers, and trashing a tavern with Billy's love interest Kate (Phoebe Cates). As the town descends into gremlinized chaos, the two humans (and Gizmo) must find a way to wipe out the horde... and if they miss only one, it'll start all over again.

Personally I find most Christmas movies a little too sappy and sentimental. So for people who feel that way, a Yuletide horror/comedy is simply ideal -- it's sort of a mad hybrid of early Peter Jackson splattergore, Frank Capra snow-sprinkled Christmastime, and a bunch of sly movie homages and send-ups ("Forbidden Planet," "Wizard of Oz" and "Snow White" amongst others).

But the real fun is in watching the movie's balance between nasty and cuddly -- Joe Dante happily veers between sweet moments and grotesquely funny violence (such as Billy's mom messily killing gremlins with a variety of kitchen implements), with the best example being the malevolent Mrs. Deagle being flung out an upstairs window by fa-la-la-la-LAing gremlins. Completely sick, and gutsplittingly funn.

And Dante sprinkles it with more G-rated comedy that borders on cartoonish without quite crossing, such as the kid in the Christmas tree costume ("Don't ask!") and the gremlins destroying a local pub when they aren't watching Disney movies (is this a message about Disney?). It all climaxes in some literally explosive showdowns with the gremlins -- and particularly with Stripe, their ghastly little leader.

Galligan and Cates are thoroughly solid as the teenage heroes, especially when Cates gives her heartbreaking speech about the horrible experience that made her hate Christmas. In fact, all the actors do a solid job -- the evil old landlady who serves as a sort of Wicked Witch of the West/Scrooge hybrid, the cranky old veteran, the crackpot inventor and the wise old Chinese guy.

But the showstopper is Gizmo -- tiny, round, fuzzy and wide-eyed, with a babyish squeaky voice and a liking for toy cars and 3-D glasses. Rarely has a puppet been so bloody cute and endearing. His complete opposite is Stripe, a gremlin amongst gremlins -- malevolent and gleefully sadistic, he seems smart enough to revel in the idea of destroying the town.

"Gremlins" is a brilliant horror/comedy that infuses a perfect American town with a little mayhem and gore, as well as some wickedly funny little nasties. Definitely a must-see.
